items.title: Learning JS framework concepts by building one
items.content:
#â€‹666 â€” December 7, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Learn How Modern JS Frameworks Work by Building One â€” Building things is a great way to learn, even if you donâ€™t end up using what you built. Even better is when someone whoâ€™s already built something successful introduces you to the process. Nolan doesnâ€™t go super deep but far enough to whet your appetite and for you to learn a few things by taking itÂ further.

Nolan Lawson

ğŸš€ Â Astro 4.0 Released â€” The new major release of the Astro content-site framework is just out, including a new dev toolbar, automatic i18n routing, new view transition APIs, and more. Thereâ€™s also, experimentally, incremental content caching. Upgrading is simple â€“ an npx @astrojs/upgrade away for most folks.

Astro

Streamline API Development With Postman Workspaces â€” Postman workspaces give teams shared access to the API tools they need to solve problems together. They are the go-to place for development teams to collaborate and move quickly while staying on theÂ sameÂ page.

Postman sponsor

Maglev: V8â€™s Fastest Optimizing JIT â€” An interesting look under the hood of how the V8 JavaScript engine (as used in Chrome, Node.js and elsewhere) continues to get faster thanks to work on its Maglev JIT compiler which sits between the existing Sparkplug and TurboFan compilers (which both have distinct compilation speed vs code performanceÂ tradeoffs).

The V8 Team

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“Š The WebAssembly vs JavaScript (PDF) paper compares the energy requirements and performance of JS and WASM on the Web. Spoiler: "WebAssembly is faster than JavaScript and even more energyÂ efficient."

  • A recap of the Electron ecosystem in 2023.

  • The New Stack weighs up the pros and cons of using ReactÂ today.

  • Talk about going down a rabbit hole, but did you know it's possible to use Nuxt, Vue and Tailwind CSS to build an Adobe Premier Pro plugin?

  • Popular ingress service ngrok has unveiled a JavaScript SDK to add secure ingress to Node apps.

  • The Construct 3 2D game engine now supports TypeScript.

RELEASES:

  • Electron 28 â€“ Now with ESM support, Chromium 120 & Node.jsÂ 18.18.2.

  • Fresh 1.6 â€“ The Deno-based webÂ framework.

  • React Native 0.73 â€“ Now with full Android 14 support, Kotlin becomes the recommended language for Android, andÂ more.

  • HTML5 Boilerplate v9.0 â€“ Blast from theÂ past!

  • Redux 5.0, Redux Toolkit 2.0, and more.

  • Node.js v21.4.0 (Current), Qwik 1.3, and Redwood 6.5

ğŸ“„Â Articles & Tutorials

Prettier's CLI: A Performance Deep Dive â€” Weâ€™ve recently written about the bounty the Prettier project put up (and how Biome won it) but Prettier has also been working on itself by hiring the author of this post to find and implement performance improvements, all while sticking withÂ JavaScript.

Fabio Spampinato

The Complete Puppeteer Cheatsheet â€” If you want to control a headless Chrome browser from JavaScript, Puppeteer is forÂ you.

Mohan Ganesan

Accelerate Your API Development with Postman Collection Templates â€” Browse 70+ free and customizable templates to jump-start your API design, documentation, development, and testingÂ workflows.

Postman sponsor

How Marketing Changed OOP in JavaScript â€” A look at JavaScriptâ€™s earliest history and its prototypalÂ nature.

Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez

Goodbye, Clean Code â€” Much as Donald Knuth warned us away from premature optimization, here Dan Abramov tells us to beware of premature refactoring andÂ de-duplication. (A golden oldie post fromÂ 2020.)

Dan Abramov

I Replaced npm, yarn and nvm with pnpm â€” npm hasnâ€™t been the only package manager in town for many years.

Pawel Grzybek

Advanced Patterns for Taking Page Element Screenshots withÂ Playwright
Liran Tal

TypeScript's Hidden Feature: Subtypes
Tim Johns

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

TSDiagram: Diagrams as Code with TypeScript â€” Draft diagrams quickly with TypeScript. Define data models through top-level type aliases and interfaces and it automatically lays out things out in an efficient way. GitHubÂ repo.

Andrei Neculaesei

StyleX: Meta's CSS-in-JS Styling System â€” A newly open sourced â€œCSS-in-JSâ€ library from Meta made up of a JavaScript syntax and compiler for styling web apps. Jack Herrington has â–¶ï¸Â a 13-minute screencast taking a practicalÂ look.

Goel and Gallagher (Meta)

Simplify Debugging with Console Ninja's Predictive Logging â€” Smart predictions and ahead of time logging saves you multiple iterations of adding logs and re-running your app to get the values youÂ need.

Wallaby Team sponsor

tsParticles 3.0: Particles, Confetti and Fireworks for Your Pages â€” Create customizable particle related effects for use on the Web. Uses the regular 2D canvas for broadÂ support.

Matteo Bruni

Culori: A General-Purpose Color Manipulation Library â€” Supports most color spaces and formats defined in the CSS Colors Level 4 spec and can parse, convert, mix, create color differences, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Moqups

Perfume.js 9.2: Web Performance Library for Measuring User-CentricÂ Metrics â€” A tiny web perf monitoring library that reports data back to your favorite analytics tool and supports the latest browser performance APIs for precise metrics on things like first paint, total blocking time,Â etc.

Leonardo Zizzamia

Timenames: A Unique Name for Each Second of the Day â€” The author had an app and wanted to create more interesting unique filenames without using the time directly. Thereâ€™s a live demo showing the names inÂ action.

Ankur Seth

YouTube.js 8.0: A Wrapper Around YouTube's Private 'InnerTube' API â€” It uses the same behind the scenes API as official YouTube clients, rather than the official developer API, so, as always, your mileage mayÂ vary.

LuanRT

Feel the Power of More Than 420,000 Teammates and WorkÂ #LikeABosch

Bosch sponsor

  • Storybook 7.6 â€“ The frontend UI componentÂ workshop.

  • Mantine 7.3 â€“ Full featured React componentÂ suite.

  • swup 4.5 â€“ Page transition library for server-renderedÂ sites.

  • wavesurfer.js 7.5 â€“ Audio waveform rendering andÂ playing.

  • Nano Events 9.0 â€“ An event emitter library in 107Â bytes.

  • AdminJS 7.5 â€“ Admin interface forÂ webapps.

  • AVA 6.0 â€“ Popular test runner forÂ Node.

items.title: Every Framework Everywhere All at Once
items.content:
#â€‹665 â€” November 30, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Eliminating JS Framework Lock-in with Web Components? â€” Can you build an app where each component is using a different framework? Amazingly, yes. Web components aren't new but are 'having a moment' and Jake demos an interesting, if contrived, use case. He explains: â€œSay youâ€™re writing a Vue app and you really want to use a library thatâ€™s only available as a React component. You can wrap that library in a web component and use it in your VueÂ app...â€

Jake Lazaroff

Announcing Deno Cron â€” Deno adds a cron-style feature to run code on a pre-defined schedule using Deno.cron. This works locally (behind --unstable) in a long-running process, but on Deno Deploy it analyzes the definition and runs the code on time, as youâ€™d expect, with no extra workÂ needed.

Zinkovsky and Jiang (Deno)

Feel the Power of More Than 420,000 Teammates and Work #LikeABosch â€” At Bosch, we shape the future with high-quality technologies and services to inspire people and improve their lives. And itâ€™s our people who make us remarkable. Our success is your success. Letâ€™s celebrate together. LearnÂ more.

Bosch sponsor

The Biome Formatter Wins the 'Prettier Challenge' â€” Two weeks ago, the creator of Prettier put up a $10k bounty for a Rust-powered code formatter that could pass over 95% of Prettierâ€™s tests. Biome, the toolchain forked from Rome, has already managed to claim the prize, topped up by furtherÂ contributors.

Biome

ğŸ¤”Â There's a post from the Prettier POV where @vjeux explains why he offered the bounty: he felt a 'a lack of competition' was holding PrettierÂ back.

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“º Evan You, creator of Vue.js, presented an update on the state of Vue and Vite for VueConf Toronto attendees. (48Â minutes.)

  • ğŸŸ© The two LTS Node.js branches have received releases backporting features from newer versions: Node v20.10.0 (LTS) gains WebSocket and an experimental flag to auto-detect ESM code. Node v18.19.0 (LTS) gets npm 10 and tweaks for customization hooks andÂ loaders.

  • ğŸ™ï¸ Off The Main Thread is a new podcast featuring Jake Archibald and Surma (both formerly of Google / HTTPÂ 203).

  • ğŸ‚ Not to do with JS â€“ though some of you may use it â€“ but Notepad++ is 20 years old. It's a popular open source code editor and Notepad replacement for Windows.

  • ğŸ™‹ The State of JavaScript 2023 survey is still open toÂ take.

RELEASES:

  • Passport 0.7 â€“ Popular authentication middleware for Express-basedÂ apps.

  • eta (Î·) 3.2 â€“ Embedded JS template engine for Node, Deno, andÂ browsers.

  • Fable 4.6 â€“ F# to JavaScriptÂ transpiler.

ğŸ“„Â Articles & Tutorials

â–¶Â Â 10 JavaScript Changes You (May Have) Missed in 2023 â€” Weâ€™ve covered most of these, but this is still a productive refresher in just six minutes, covering things like toSorted(), iOS Web Push, Next.js updates, Angular 17, and the rapid rise of Bun.

Fireship on YouTube

Fireship is a great channel for these sort of quick-fire roundups, and if you want more 100+ JavaScript Concepts You Need to Know is a funÂ one.

Tracking Frontend JS Exceptions with Playwright Fixtures â€” Playwright is commonly used to test frontend apps and ensure theyâ€™re rendering and behaving correctly, but what if you want to be sure the underlying JavaScript is working as expected too? Stefan has someÂ tips.

Stefan Judis

Lesser Spotted React Mistakes and How to AvoidÂ Them â€” Read about common pitfalls that occur when writing React code. Cut, paste, & try the included examples in your ownÂ code.

Sonar sponsor

A Deep Dive into CheerpJ 3.0: A WASM JVM for the Browser â€” A look at an interesting WebAssembly-based Java Virtual Machine that runs client side in the browser, opening up bidirectional Java-JavaScript interop, if you need it. Note that itâ€™s commercial, but can be used free for personal projects andÂ evaluation.

Pignotti, Bates, and De Rossi

A Simple WebSocket Benchmark: Node vs Bun â€” Using as â€˜textbookâ€™ an example of WebSocket communication as possible, the author pits Node and Bun against eachÂ other.

Daniel Lemire

Svelte Through the Eyes of a React Developer
Ido Shamun

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

FullCalendar: A Full Sized JavaScript Calendar Control â€” An interesting option if you want a Google Calendar style experience for your own apps. Has connectors for React, Vue and Angular. The base version is MIT licensed, but thereâ€™s a commercial version too with extraÂ features.

Adam Shaw

Knip 3.3: Find Unused Files, Dependencies and Exports â€” Finds unused files, dependencies and exports in your projects and lets you cut/knip themÂ away.

Lars Kappert

ğŸ˜ Knip has continued to evolve a lot this year, and now also has a snazzy newÂ homepage. You can also learn more about what's new inÂ 3.x.

Inline REPL Anywhere in Your Code â€” Execute context aware code snippets directly in your editor, anywhere in your project, even if your application/tests areÂ notÂ working.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Syntax.js: Code Syntax Highlighting Library â€” There are many long standing options in this area, such as Prism and highlight.js, but itâ€™s interesting to see a fresh and lightweightÂ take.

William Troup

ai2html: Turn Adobe Illustrator Files into HTML â€” We noticed this tool being used by the Financial Times to share graphs they've designed, and the result is really good. This project isn't new, but we haven't shared it before, it's well maintained, and there are lots ofÂ examples.

The New York Times Company

aws-lite: A New Node.js-Powered AWS API Client â€” AWS does a good job with its APIs and tooling, but sometimes their approach is a little heavyweight. aws-lite provides a simpler, faster option. â€œYou can think of it as a community-driven alternative to AWSâ€™s JavaScriptÂ SDK.â€

Begin

Hire Vetted Developers in US Time Zones, Fast

Revelo sponsor

  • Neutralinojs 4.15.0 â€“ Cross-platform desktop app framework â€“ lighter than Electron as it uses the locally available browserÂ engine.

  • jest-image-snapshot 6.3 â€“ Jest matcher for imageÂ comparisons.

  • Mongoose 8.0 â€“ MongoDB object modellingÂ approach.

  • edit-in-place 1.9 â€“ Edit in place library for AngularÂ apps.

  • Jotai 2.6 â€“ Simple, flexible state management forÂ React.

  • sql.js 1.9 â€“ SQLite 3.44 compiled toÂ JavaScript.

  • React Share 5.0 â€“ Social media sharingÂ buttons.

  • np 9.0 â€“ A better npm publish.

  • pnpm 8.11 â€“ Fast, disk space efficient packageÂ manager.

NOTABLE QUOTABLE

â€œAs a principal engineer, I view it as my role to keep us off the bleeding edge as much as possible. That way, when we really do need to innovate, we have the capacity to do so. And when we don't need to, we can go really freaking fast.â€

___
Nicole Tietz

items.title: The unbearable weight of massive JavaScript
items.content:
#â€‹664 â€” November 23, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Time to Take the State of JavaScript 2023 â€” The long standing State of JavaScript survey is back for another run at figuring out what the community is up to and what tools weâ€™re using. The results are always illuminating and weâ€™ll share the tastiest parts onceÂ available.

Devographics

â–¶Â Â The Unbearable Weight of Massive JavaScript â€” An extensive talk looking at what can be achieved by simplifying web architecture, chiefly by using new or upcoming Web Platform APIs and getting back to building fast, maintainable, user-friendlyÂ frontends. Slidedeck.

Ryan Townsend

Stop Building Auth, Start Building Apps with EdgeDB + Next.js â€” Itâ€™s hard enough to come up with an idea worth trying. See how EdgeDB and our new authentication extension makes it easy to go from idea to working application in record time usingÂ Next.js.

EdgeDB sponsor

TypeScript 5.3 Released â€” The latest edition of the type-enhanced JavaScript superset is here. The headline feature is full support for the import attributes proposal (as it currently stands, at stage 3 in TC39), but there are many enhancements around type narrowing, interactive inlay hints for types in editors, and more. Not the biggest update, but progressÂ nonetheless.

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

Vite 5.0 Released â€” The Vite suite of frontend tooling may have started life in the Vue.js world, but is now used by projects aplenty including SvelteKit, Remix, and Astro. v5 now uses Rollup 4, removes many deprecated features, and requires Node 18+. Thereâ€™s a migration guide to help with your v4 to v5Â progression.

Evan You and Contributors

IN BRIEF:

  • The Node.js 20.x runtime is now available on AWS Lambda.

  • ğŸ A bumper list of dev-related tools & services running Black Friday deals.

  • GitHub looks at what's new in the latest Git release: GitÂ 2.43.

  • The AWS Amplify team teases 'Gen 2' of their fullstack appÂ platform.

RELEASES:

  • â­ï¸ Transformers.js v2.9 â€“ State of the art ML in JavaScript. v2.9 adds support for depth estimation, zero-shot object detection, and optical documentÂ understanding.

  • Redux Toolkit 2.0 rc.0, Redux 5.0 rc.0, React-Redux 9.0 rc.0 â€“ Initial RCs with better packaging and smaller bundles. Final releases dueÂ soon.

  • Bun 1.0.14 â€“ Introduces a high-perf globbing API for matching files andÂ strings.

  • Rspack 0.4 including Rsbuild 0.1 â€“ A fast Rust-based webÂ bundler.

  • Node v21.2.0 (Current) and Node v20.10.0 (LTS)

  • Starlight 0.13.0 â€“ Beautiful docs sites atopÂ Astro.

ğŸ“„Â Articles & Tutorials

â–¶Â Â 4 Web Devs, 1 App Idea â€” Salma Alam-Naylor, Scott Tolinski, and Eve Porcello join Jason Lengstorf to kick off a fun new series where several developers all implement the same type of app, show off how they went about it, and react to each otherâ€™s approaches. Svelte, Astro, and Next.js each make anÂ appearance.

Learn with Jason

Promises Training â€” Practice working with promises through a curated collection of interactiveÂ challenges. Aimed at developers with at least an intermediate understanding of promises who want to digÂ deeper.

Henrique Inonhe

JavaScript Error and Performance Monitoring â€” Track, trace, debug and resolve JavaScript errors across platforms. Are your releases that easy? JoinÂ usÂ live.

Sentry sponsor

An Attempted Taxonomy of Web Components â€” A collection of open-source web components (and lessons learned from using them) that may help you on your journey in this complex, developingÂ space.

Zach Leatherman

Using OpenAI APIs to Analyze Automated Test Failures â€” A look at how to develop a Nightwatch.js plugin which sends the test failure and associated errors to a service that integrates with OpenAIâ€™s platform to analyze said errors and provide actionableÂ feedback.

Andrei Rusu

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Bruno: An Open-Source HTTP API Exploration App â€” There are a lot of â€˜API clientâ€™ tools like this, commercial and non-commercial, with varying levels of features, but this is an open source one entirely built in JavaScript with a fully-offline ethos some might appreciate. GitHubÂ repo.

Anoop M D, Anusree P S and Contributors

debounce 2.0: Delay Function Calls Until a Set Time Elapses â€” If you donâ€™t want something to run too often, debouncing is the strategy for you and this library makes it simple. v2 adds types and brings the code up to modernÂ standards.

Sindre Sorhus et al.

Level Up Your UX With Bryntum â€” Empower your users with advanced widgets like data grids, calendars, schedulers, and GanttÂ charts.

Bryntum sponsor

H3: A Minimal HTTP Framework for Multiple JS Platforms â€” Aims to be as universal as possible and works across numerous platforms, including Node, while offering the basic HTTP framework features and a compatibility layer with Express middleware. v1.9 justÂ landed.

UnJS

request-animation-frames: Use requestAnimationFrame Anywhere â€” The latest library from the one-man module powerhouse, Sindre Sorhus. The idea this time is to allow you to use requestAnimationFrame in any JavaScript environment. The implementation is delightfullyÂ simple.

Sindre Sorhus

Spectral.js: A More 'Paint-Like' Color Mixing Library â€” If you have two colors to transition between, just tweening the RGB values can result in some rather ugly intermediate colors. Spectral.js uses Kubelkaâ€“Munk theory which more closely matches how paints work for a visually satisfyingÂ result.

Ronald van Wijnen

'A Node + TypeScript + ts-node + ESM Experience That Works' â€” Itâ€™s just three files: package.json, tsconfig.json and a utilitiesÂ file.

Khalid Zoabi

A Non-Cloud Alternative to Google Forms That Has It All

SURVEYJS sponsor

ğŸ–¼ medium-zoom 1.1: A Library for Medium-Style Image Zooming â€” Responsive, can load a higher definition version of an image on zoom, and mouse, keyboard and gesture friendly. Now we just need a library that can cover up the bottom half of a page with junk like Medium also does now. Demo.

FranÃ§ois Chalifour

  • gridstack.js 10.0 â€“ Build interactive dashboard panelsÂ quickly.

  • MQTT.js 5.3 â€“ MQTT client for Node and browser.

  • Piscina 4.2 â€“ Node.js worker thread pool implementation.

  • (Official) MongoDB Node.js Driver 6.3

  • SQL Formatter 14.0 â€“ Pretty print SQL queries.

Job Listing

Full Stack TypeScript Software Engineer - [Remote Europe] â€” Marker.io is a visual bug-reporting tool for the web. Join our dev team and work remotely (Stack: Node.js, Vue.js &Â MongoDB).
Marker.io

NOTABLE QUOTABLE

â€œProgramming isn't about what you know; it's about what you can figure out.â€

___
Chris Pine (author of Learn to Program)

P.S. Medium is ğŸ—‘ï¸. If you don't want to host your own blog, try Hashnode, dev.to, Bear, or even throw Markdown at GitHub Gists â€“ it'll provide a better readerÂ experience and we'll be more likely to link toÂ it.
items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹664 â€” November 23, 2023


Read on the Web



JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
Time to Take the State of JavaScript 2023 â€” The long standing State of JavaScript survey is back for another run at figuring out what the community is up to and what tools weâ€™re using. The results are always illuminating and weâ€™ll share the tastiest parts onceÂ available.
Devographics 


  
  
â–¶Â Â The Unbearable Weight of Massive JavaScript â€” An extensive talk looking at what can be achieved by simplifying web architecture, chiefly by using new or upcoming Web Platform APIs and getting back to building fast, maintainable, user-friendlyÂ frontends. Slidedeck.
Ryan Townsend 


  
  
Stop Building Auth, Start Building Apps with EdgeDB + Next.js â€” Itâ€™s hard enough to come up with an idea worth trying. See how EdgeDB and our new authentication extension makes it easy to go from idea to working application in record time usingÂ Next.js.
EdgeDB sponsor


  
  
TypeScript 5.3 Released â€” The latest edition of the type-enhanced JavaScript superset is here. The headline feature is full support for the import attributes proposal (as it currently stands, at stage 3 in TC39), but there are many enhancements around type narrowing, interactive inlay hints for types in editors, and more. Not the biggest update, but progressÂ nonetheless.
Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft) 


  
  
Vite 5.0 Released â€” The Vite suite of frontend tooling may have started life in the Vue.js world, but is now used by projects aplenty including SvelteKit, Remix, and Astro. v5 now uses Rollup 4, removes many deprecated features, and requires Node 18+. Thereâ€™s a migration guide to help with your v4 to v5Â progression.

Node v21.2.0 (Current) and Node v20.10.0 (LTS)

Svelte, Astro, and Next.js each make anÂ appearance.

Promises Training â€” Practice working with promises through a curated collection of interactiveÂ challenges. Aimed at developers with at least an intermediate understanding of promises who want to digÂ deeper.
Henrique Inonhe 


  
  
JavaScript Error and Performance Monitoring â€” Track, trace, debug and resolve JavaScript errors across platforms. Are your releases that easy? JoinÂ usÂ live.
Sentry sponsor


  
  
An Attempted Taxonomy of Web Components â€” A collection of open-source web components (and lessons learned from using them) that may help you on your journey in this complex, developingÂ space.

Using OpenAI APIs to Analyze Automated Test Failures â€” A look at how to develop a Nightwatch.js plugin which sends the test failure and associated errors to a service that integrates with OpenAIâ€™s platform to analyze said errors and provide actionableÂ feedback.
Andrei Rusu 


ğŸ› Â Code & Tools 




  





  
  
Bruno: An Open-Source HTTP API Exploration App â€” There are a lot of â€˜API clientâ€™ tools like this, commercial and non-commercial, with varying levels of features, but this is an open source one entirely built in JavaScript with a fully-offline ethos some might appreciate. GitHubÂ repo.

debounce 2.0: Delay Function Calls Until a Set Time Elapses â€” If you donâ€™t want something to run too often, debouncing is the strategy for you and this library makes it simple. v2 adds types and brings the code up to modernÂ standards.

items.title: Digging into explicit resource management
items.content:
#â€‹663 â€” November 16, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Prettier 3.1 Released â€” The popular opinionated code formatter has a new release including support for the new control flow syntax in Angular 17 plus a new, experimental formatting option for ternary expressions (as in x ? y : z) explained in more depth in "A curious case of theÂ ternaries."

Alex Rattray

ğŸ¤” With an aim to making code formatting even faster, Prettier's co-creator has put up a $10k bounty for any Rust project that passes >95% of Prettier's tests.

Exploring Explicit Resource Management in JS â€” A practical look at the idea of explicit resource management, an idea both currently at stage 3 in TC39 (and partly supported in TypeScript 5.2) that makes it easier to â€˜clean upâ€™ resources once they are no longer used orÂ needed.

Ilia Pozdnyakov

Build Interactive, Live Video Applications with AmazonÂ IVS â€” Amazon Interactive Video Service (Amazon IVS) allows developers to create dynamic video experiences, such as collaborative real-time livestreams. Check out the new ivs.rocks to find code samples, demos, and other resources. Click here to getÂ started.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

On HTML Web Components â€” â€œWith web components, you might even say Reactâ€™s component model is being ported to the browser. But itâ€™s being done in a way that works to enhance how the web already works, not replaceÂ itâ€.

Jim Nielsen

A Review of Lightweight JavaScript Frameworks â€” This overview is targeted at Django (i.e. Python) developers but if you, too, want to avoid larger frameworks like React or Angular, you might appreciate this look at numerous alternatives from Stimulus and htmx to more oblique options like LaravelÂ Livewire.

Michael Yin

  • ğŸ¥³ AWS is celebrating a huge release with v6 of the AWS Amplify JavaScript library which includes full support for Next.js App Router and ServerÂ Actions.

  • ğŸŒ Node.js TSC member Yagiz Nizipli is suggesting using Biome for code formatting in Node, since ESLint has deprecated its core formatting rules.

  • ğŸ‘¾ The winners of React Jam, a recent React-based game development contest, have been revealed. An entry I enjoyed was useChess, a set of chess-based puzzles.

  • â–¶ï¸ If you've wondered what the big deal is about Astro, James Q Quick went on the Software Engineering Daily podcast and explained Astro pretty well.

  • ğŸµ Someone's recorded â–¶ï¸Â aÂ rap music video about TypeScript..

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v21.2.0 (Current)

  • visx 3.5 â€“ D3-based visualization primitives forÂ React.

  • fx 31.0 â€“ Powerful terminal JSONÂ viewer.

  • Astro 3.5, Ember 5.4, and Prisma 5.6.

ğŸ“„Â Articles & Tutorials

67 Browser-Based Debugging Tricks â€” A list of useful, â€˜not-obviousâ€™ hacks to get the most out of the browserâ€™s DevTools. Assumes a reasonable existing understanding of saidÂ tools.

Alan Norbauer

Exploring V8's Strings: Implementation and Optimizations â€” Note: This is very technical and most JavaScript developers do not need to go this deep. That aside, this is a fantastic look under the covers of how the V8 engine handles strings, including the optimizations used that allow it to go toe to toe with languages likeÂ C++.

Ilia Pozdnyakov

JavaScript Scratchpad for VSÂ Code â€” Quokka.js is the #1 tool for exploring/testing JavaScript with edit-continue experience to see realtime execution and runtimeÂ values.

Wallaby Team sponsor

â–¶Â Â An Overview of Angular 17's New Built-In Control Flow â€” Angular 17 was released last week and a significant enhancement was support for a new syntax in templates that looks and feels moreÂ JavaScript-y.

Dmytro Mezhenskyi

Moving Back to React (from Preact) â€” Preact felt like a logical, lightweight choice to this team at one time, but theyâ€™ve switched to React for better compatibility with Next.js, among other things. Their page weight is up slightly, but they feel the tradeoff is worthÂ it.

Ante BariÄ‡ (Dailyâ€¤Dev)

My Journey to 3x Faster Builds: Trimming Barrel File Imports â€” â€œI maintain a small frontend application (4K LOC) which uses Vite as the compiler. The production build, using npm run build, was taking 26 secs on Github Actions. It seemed awfully slow for such a small application. I decided to investigateÂ why.â€

Ramana Venkata

Can Bun Eat Nodeâ€™s 'Lunch'? â€” An experiment in migrating a codebase (a restaurant voting app called Lunch) from Node over to Bun and seeing how itÂ fares.

Jeffrey Carl Faden

Feel the Power of More Than 420,000 Teammates and Work #LikeABosch

Bosch sponsor

How to Use NPM Packages Outside of Node â€” Learn how to run NPM packages in â€˜other placesâ€™ like serverless platforms, the browser, andÂ beyond.

George MacKerron (Neon)

What I Learned Building an Audio Plugins System for the Web
Ben Wiley

Rust for JavaScript Developers: An Overview of Testing
Joshua Mo

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

gsplat.js: A Gaussian Splatting Library â€” Gaussian splatting is an increasingly popular graphics rendering techniques where rather than render millions of tiny, textured triangles in a scene, you get a more wild paintball-like splatter fest, where each paintball creates a smooth, colorful blob instead of a rigid shape. This demo is both simple andÂ striking.

Dylan Ebert

Reveal.js 5.0: The HTML Presentation Framework â€” A way to build presentations using standard Web technologies. The projectâ€™s homepage is, itself, such a presentation. v5.0 adds support for â€˜scroll modeâ€™ which essentially turns presentations into more typically scrolling Web experiences â€“ demo.

Hakim El Hattab

ğŸ–ï¸ Marker.io: Collect Bug Reports With Annotations & Session Replay â€” Collect feedback on live websites. Get dev-friendly bug reports with screenshots, URLs, console logs & sessionÂ replay.

Marker.io sponsor

Datasheet Grid: An Airtable-like React Component â€” If youâ€™ve got an array of objects and you want a way for users to manipulate them, this is for you. Itâ€™s not going to replace a spreadsheet or an extensive data grid framework, but itâ€™s a mature solution featuring smooth animations, virtualized rows/columns, keyboard navigation, andÂ more.

Nicolas Keller

Perfect Freehand: A Library for Creating Better 'Freehand' Lines â€” You can try it out here. Makes your e-signature not look like chicken scratch! Might be useful for drawingÂ apps.

Steve Ruiz

Wild Wild Path v5: Object Property Paths with Wildcards and Regexps â€” A 'wild' way to access properties in objects (which can be deeply nested) by way of string based queries that support wildcards andÂ regexes. The examples help communicate theÂ idea.

ehmicky

@storybook-test: More Streamlined and Powerful Storybook Testing â€” @storybook/test consolidates the API of @storybook/jest and @storybook/testing-library into a new, single package, powered byÂ Vitest.

Kasper Peulen

  • Marked 10.0 â€“ Markdown parser andÂ compiler. There's also marked-terminal 6.1 which lets you render Marked-processed Markdown on theÂ terminal.

  • HumanizeDuration.js 3.31.0 â€“ Turn milliseconds into textual durations in numerous naturalÂ languages.

  • actions/github-script 7.0 â€“ Script the GitHub API in GitHubÂ Actions.

  • Plasmo v0.84.0 â€“ "Like Next.js for browserÂ extensions."

  • PDFKit 0.14.0 â€“ PDF generation for Node and browser.

  • React Joyride 2.7 â€“ Create guided tours in yourÂ apps.

Job Listing

Full Stack TypeScript Software Engineer - [Remote Europe] â€” Marker.io is a visual bug-reporting tool for the web. Join our dev team and work remotely (Stack: Node.js, Vue.js &Â MongoDB).

NOTABLE QUOTABLE

â€œWhen you choose a language, youâ€™re choosing more than a set of technical trade-offs â€“ youâ€™re choosing aÂ community.â€

___
Joshua Bloch
